feature: Create end-to-end governance workflow examples with working code
description: Create comprehensive examples demonstrating complete governance workflows from policy creation through enforcement to audit logging, targeting Enterprise DevOps/MLOps engineers deploying AI systems. The examples will show: defining constitutional policies, enforcing them on agent actions, handling HITL approvals, and auditing decisions.

phases.name: Planning and Analysis
phases.description: Analyze existing examples and design the end-to-end governance workflow example

subtasks.title: Review existing examples and identify gaps
subtasks.description: Analyze the existing 3 examples (basic-policy-evaluation, ai-model-approval, data-access-control) to understand patterns and identify what's missing for a complete end-to-end workflow
acceptance_criteria: Clear understanding of what needs to be added
subtasks.notes: Completed comprehensive analysis. Created analysis-findings.md with 10 common patterns and 10 critical gaps identified. Recorded discoveries and gotchas to session context.

subtasks.title: Design end-to-end governance workflow architecture
subtasks.description: Design a comprehensive example that demonstrates: policy creation, enforcement, HITL approvals, and audit logging in a realistic AI agent deployment scenario
acceptance_criteria: Integration points with ACGS-2 core identified
subtasks.notes: Completed comprehensive architecture design. Created architecture-design.md with: 6-step workflow diagram, component architecture, sequence diagrams, 6 detailed use case scenarios (low-risk auto-approve, medium-risk with compliance, high-risk HITL, constitutional violation denial, HITL rejection, timeout/escalation), integration points with ACGS-2 core (constitutional policy, OPA, audit trail, HITL workflow, policy management, observability), technology stack, file structure, implementation priorities (MVP/Enhanced/Optional), and risk mitigation strategies.

subtasks.title: Define example scope and components
subtasks.description: Define the specific components for Example 04: what services, policies, and workflows will be demonstrated
subtasks.notes: Completed comprehensive component specification. Created component-specification.md (1,000+ lines) defining: 35 files across 7 directories, 7 Python modules with detailed class/method specs, 4 Rego policies with complete rules, 11 concrete agent action examples across 5 risk levels, Docker Compose configuration for OPA/PostgreSQL/Redis, complete documentation plan, testing strategy, and implementation priorities. All acceptance criteria met: components finalized, file structure planned, policy types identified, agent actions defined. Ready for Phase 2 implementation.

phases.name: Example 04 Structure Setup
phases.description: Create the directory structure, configuration files, and skeleton for Example 04

subtasks.title: Create Example 04 directory structure
subtasks.description: Set up the complete directory structure for the end-to-end governance workflow example following the pattern of existing examples
subtasks.notes: Created complete directory structure for Example 04 with all 35 files across 6 directories (src/, policies/, tests/, docs/, scripts/, plus root files). Structure follows component specification exactly and matches patterns from existing examples. All Python packages have __init__.py files, shell scripts are executable, and all placeholder files are created ready for implementation.

subtasks.title: Create Docker Compose configuration
subtasks.description: Create compose.yaml for OPA and any other required services (e.g., PostgreSQL for audit logs, Redis for state)
acceptance_criteria: Database service for audit logs (if needed)
subtasks.notes: Created comprehensive compose.yaml with OPA (rootless), PostgreSQL 16 (with audit log storage), and optional Redis (enhanced profile). All services have health checks, proper networking, environment variable configuration, and volume mounts. Includes extensive quick reference documentation following patterns from Examples 01-03.

subtasks.title: Create requirements.txt and Python project setup
subtasks.description: Define Python dependencies and project configuration
subtasks.notes: Created requirements.txt and pyproject.toml following existing patterns from Examples 01-03 and ACGS-2 core services. Defined core dependencies (requests, psycopg2-binary, pydantic, python-dotenv), optional enhanced features (redis, fastapi, uvicorn), and development dependencies (pytest, black, mypy, ruff). Configured tool settings for pytest, coverage, ruff, black, and mypy. All dependencies have proper version constraints compatible with Python >=3.11. Constitutional hash included in headers.

phases.name: Policy Implementation
phases.description: Create Rego policies demonstrating constitutional governance, risk assessment, and HITL requirements

subtasks.title: Create constitutional policy definition
subtasks.description: Write Rego policy defining constitutional principles and constraints for AI agent actions
subtasks.notes: Completed constitutional policy implementation. Created comprehensive constitutional.rego (324 lines, 9.7KB) with: constitutional hash validation (cdd01ef066bc6cf2), 6 constitutional principles (Transparency, Accountability, Privacy Protection, Data Minimization, Human Oversight, Fairness), comprehensive denial reasons for debugging, edge case handling (missing fields, invalid purposes, unauthorized access), well-documented with inline comments, follows patterns from Examples 01-03. Policy validates actions against constitutional constraints as the first step in the governance workflow. All acceptance criteria met: validates against constitutional hash, defines core principles, handles edge cases, well documented with comments. Committed to git.

subtasks.title: Create agent action enforcement policy
subtasks.description: Write Rego policy that evaluates agent actions against constitutional principles and risk thresholds
subtasks.notes: Completed agent action enforcement policy implementation. Created comprehensive agent_actions.rego (431 lines) with: risk calculation formula (base_risk × env_multiplier × resource_modifier), 7 action types with base risk scores (read_data: 0.2, write_data: 0.5, modify_config: 0.6, deploy_model: 0.7, access_pii: 0.8, execute_code: 0.85, delete_resource: 0.9), environment multipliers (development: 0.5, staging: 0.75, production: 1.0), resource sensitivity modifiers (PII: 1.2, customer data: 1.15, production databases: 1.1), risk categories (low: 0-0.3, medium: 0.3-0.7, high: 0.7-0.9, critical: 0.9+), comprehensive action-specific authorization rules for all 7 action types, detailed denial reasons for each failure scenario, structured result output with risk factors and evaluation metadata. Policy uses default deny security model and follows patterns from constitutional.rego. All acceptance criteria met: evaluates all action types, implements comprehensive risk scoring with multiple factors, provides contextual evaluation based on environment and resource sensitivity, includes detailed denial reasons for debugging. Committed to git (commit 0ed6e7bda).

subtasks.title: Create HITL approval policy
subtasks.description: Write Rego policy that determines when human approval is required based on risk scores and action types
subtasks.notes: Completed HITL approval policy implementation. Created comprehensive hitl_approval.rego (285 lines, 8.4KB) with: risk threshold (0.7) for HITL requirement, always-require approval rules for 4 action types (deploy_model in production, delete_resource, access_pii, execute_code), reviewer expertise assignment (ml_safety_specialist, data_protection_officer, security_lead, senior_devops), timeout configuration (2 hours for risk < 0.8, 4 hours for risk >= 0.8), escalation logic to 4 levels (security_director, compliance_officer, ml_director, cto), human-readable rationale generation for each scenario, priority levels for approval queue (critical, high, medium, normal), bypass attempt detection and warning, structured output for workflow integration. Policy follows patterns from constitutional.rego and agent_actions.rego with comprehensive inline comments and clear sectioning. All acceptance criteria met: HITL thresholds defined, approval workflow logic implemented, reviewer requirements specified, escalation rules defined. Committed to git (commit 566929b05).

subtasks.title: Create audit logging policy
subtasks.description: Write Rego policy that defines what should be logged and how decisions are recorded
subtasks.notes: Completed comprehensive audit logging policy implementation. Created audit.rego (311 lines) with: retention period calculation based on data sensitivity (7 years for PII/health/financial/denials, 3 years for production, 1 year default), compliance tagging for 5 regulatory frameworks (SOC2 for production/denials/HITL, GDPR for PII/customer/personal data, HIPAA for health/medical/patient data, PCI-DSS for payment/card/financial, ISO27001 for production config changes and deletions), log detail level determination (detailed for denials/HITL/high-risk/compliance-tagged, summary for low-risk approvals, normal as default), metadata inclusion rules (enabled for compliance tags, production, HITL, denials, high-risk), sensitive data detection across 7 resource patterns, helper rules for production change actions, structured result output with all audit requirements. Policy follows patterns from constitutional.rego, agent_actions.rego, and hitl_approval.rego with comprehensive inline comments, clear sectioning, and rego.v1 import. All acceptance criteria met: audit requirements defined, log structure specified, compliance metadata included, retention rules defined. Committed to git (commit f14389d2f).

phases.name: Python Service Implementation
phases.description: Build Python services demonstrating the governance workflow integration

subtasks.title: Create OPA client module
subtasks.description: Build a reusable OPA client module for policy evaluation
subtasks.notes: Completed OPA client module implementation. Created comprehensive opa_client.py (374 lines) with: OPAClient class with health_check(), evaluate_policy(), evaluate_policies_batch(), clear_cache() methods; OPAConfig dataclass for flexible configuration; Custom exceptions (OPAConnectionError, OPAPolicyError, OPATimeoutError); Exponential backoff retry logic with configurable retries; Optional in-memory caching for improved performance; Persistent HTTP session for connection pooling; Context manager support (__enter__/__exit__); Comprehensive type hints using collections.abc.Callable for Python 3.11+ compatibility; Detailed docstrings and logging throughout; Convenience evaluate_policy() function for one-off evaluations. Follows patterns from Examples 01-03: health check pattern from Example 01, error handling pattern from Example 02, constitutional hash in header. All acceptance criteria met: connection handling implemented, error handling robust, retry logic included, type hints and documentation complete. Committed to git (commit 69f0307f5).

subtasks.title: Create audit logger module
subtasks.description: Build module for recording governance decisions to an audit trail
subtasks.notes: Completed comprehensive audit logging module implementation. Created audit_logger.py (604 lines) with: AuditEntry dataclass with full validation and timezone handling; DatabaseConfig dataclass for connection settings; AuditLogger class with connection pooling (psycopg2); Custom exceptions (AuditLoggerError, AuditDatabaseError, AuditConnectionError); Core methods: log_decision() (append-only), query_by_id(), query_by_requester(), query_by_decision(), query_recent(), get_statistics(), health_check(); Context manager support for automatic cleanup; Comprehensive error handling and logging throughout; Type hints using Python 3.11+ style. Also created scripts/init_db.sql (194 lines) with: audit_logs table with UUID primary keys, immutable append-only design with trigger enforcement, JSONB columns for flexible metadata, comprehensive indexes for query optimization, views for compliance reporting, CHECK constraints for data integrity. Follows patterns from existing examples: constitutional hash in header, connection pooling, health check pattern from OPA client, comprehensive docstrings and type hints, context manager support, custom exceptions, modern Python 3.11+ syntax. All acceptance criteria met: structured logging implemented, timestamps and metadata included, immutable log format (database trigger prevents updates/deletes), query capabilities provided (6 query methods + statistics). Committed to git (commit f91c7252f).

subtasks.title: Create HITL approval handler
subtasks.description: Build module that simulates human-in-the-loop approval workflow
subtasks.notes: Completed comprehensive HITL handler module implementation. Created hitl_handler.py (595 lines) with: HITLConfig dataclass for flexible configuration; ApprovalRequest dataclass with UUID, risk_score, required_expertise, timeout handling, priority; ReviewerDecision dataclass with approval status, reviewer details, escalation tracking; ReviewerProfile dataclass for simulated reviewer profiles. HITLHandler class features: create_approval_request(), assign_reviewer() with 4 reviewer profiles (ml_safety_specialist, data_protection_officer, security_lead, senior_devops), simulate_review() with risk-based approval simulation (90%/70%/40% approval for low/high/critical risk), wait_for_approval(), handle_timeout() with escalation logic, get_request_status(), get_queue_statistics(), clear_queue(). Custom exceptions: HITLHandlerError, HITLTimeoutError, HITLRequestNotFoundError. Context manager support. Python 3.11+ type hints. Follows patterns from opa_client.py and audit_logger.py. Constitutional hash: cdd01ef066bc6cf2. All acceptance criteria met: approval queue management, reviewer assignment logic, timeout handling with escalation, decision recording. Committed to git (commit 876b2fded).

subtasks.title: Create governance workflow orchestrator
subtasks.description: Build main orchestrator that coordinates policy evaluation, HITL approvals, and audit logging
subtasks.notes: Completed comprehensive governance workflow orchestrator implementation. Created governance_workflow.py (696 lines) with: GovernanceDecision dataclass for complete decision response structure; GovernanceWorkflow class orchestrating full end-to-end workflow; Custom exceptions (GovernanceWorkflowError, GovernanceValidationError, GovernanceEvaluationError); 6-step workflow implementation: (1) Constitutional validation via constitutional.rego, (2) Action evaluation and risk assessment via agent_actions.rego, (3) HITL determination via hitl_approval.rego, (4) Human approval workflow handling with HITLHandler, (5) Audit logging via audit.rego and AuditLogger, (6) Final decision response construction; Comprehensive error handling with try/except blocks, custom exceptions, and error logging to audit trail; Observable execution flow with 28 logging statements throughout all workflow steps; Python 3.11+ type hints; Integration with OPAClient, AuditLogger, and HITLHandler; Default-deny security model; Detailed docstrings for all methods; Constitutional hash: cdd01ef066bc6cf2. All acceptance criteria met: end-to-end workflow implemented, all components integrated, error handling comprehensive, observable execution flow.

subtasks.title: Create CLI and interactive demo
subtasks.description: Build command-line interface and interactive demo script showing the workflow in action

subtasks.title: Create FastAPI service (optional)
subtasks.description: Build optional REST API service demonstrating production integration patterns

phases.description: Create comprehensive documentation showing how to use the example

subtasks.title: Create Example 04 README
subtasks.description: Write detailed README for the end-to-end governance workflow example

subtasks.title: Create workflow diagram and visuals
subtasks.description: Create visual diagrams showing the governance workflow, decision trees, and component interactions

subtasks.title: Create scenario walkthrough documentation
subtasks.description: Document specific scenarios with step-by-step walkthroughs showing the governance workflow in action

subtasks.title: Update examples/README.md
subtasks.description: Update the main examples README to include Example 04 in the catalog
acceptance_criteria: Difficulty level and time estimate included

phases.name: Testing and Validation
phases.description: Create tests and validate the example works end-to-end

subtasks.title: Create unit tests for Python modules
subtasks.description: Write unit tests for all Python modules (OPA client, audit logger, HITL handler)

subtasks.title: Create integration tests
subtasks.description: Write integration tests that verify the complete workflow with OPA running

subtasks.title: Create policy tests
subtasks.description: Write OPA tests for all Rego policies using OPA testing framework

subtasks.title: Manual testing and validation
subtasks.description: Perform manual end-to-end testing of all scenarios and validate documentation accuracy

phases.name: Polish and Integration
phases.description: Final polish, ensure consistency with existing examples, and integration with main docs

subtasks.title: Code quality and style consistency
subtasks.description: Ensure code follows project conventions, is properly formatted, and has consistent style with existing examples

subtasks.title: Add example to main documentation
subtasks.description: Reference the new example in main ACGS-2 documentation and getting-started guides

subtasks.title: Create CI/CD integration
subtasks.description: Ensure the example is included in CI/CD pipelines for automated testing

subtasks.title: Final review and cleanup
subtasks.description: Final review of all components, remove any temporary files, ensure everything is production-ready

final_acceptance: Example 04 demonstrates complete end-to-end governance workflow
Policy creation, enforcement, HITL approvals, and audit logging all working
Code runs successfully following README instructions
Integration with OPA and ACGS-2 core services demonstrated
Code quality matches or exceeds existing examples
Target audience (Enterprise DevOps/MLOps) can understand and use the example
